title: Philosophy / Expectations / Definition of a Patient / Use of Protocols
content:
Philosophy & Expectations

Protocols ensure the safe, efficient, and effective provision of patient care. All personnel will use these protocols to guide clinical decision-making. Safety is the final determinant for all decisions.

Goals of EMS Personnel:

  • Do no harm.
  • Improve patient outcomes while alleviating pain and suffering.
  • Provide quality prehospital care through comprehensive education, sound clinical judgment, and continuous quality improvement.

Definition of a Patient

A patient is an individual requesting or potentially needing medical evaluation or treatment. It is EMS personnel's responsibility to ensure all potential patients are offered the opportunity for evaluation, treatment, and/or transport, including those requesting "lift assistance."

Use of Protocols

  • All skill levels begin care at Skill Level 1 and progress to the provider's current certification level.
  • If ever in doubt, contact On-Line Medical Control (OLMC).
  • Medications are highlighted in blue.
  • Procedures are bolded.
  • RED, BOLDED TEXT indicates critical information.

title: Procedures in the Prehospital Environment
content:
Procedures in the Prehospital Environment

EMS personnel must be credentialed by the local Medical Director. This includes initial training, supervisory ride-alongs, continuing education, and documentation of training.

title: Communication
content:
Communication with OLMC / Receiving Facility

Use the following format for radio reports:

  • Unit Call Sign and ETA
  • Patient's age, sex, and mental status
  • Mechanism of Injury/Illness
  • Injuries/Illness
  • Signs and Symptoms
  • Treatment provided
  • Most recent vital signs

Follow local/state protocols for trauma, sepsis, STEMI, and stroke notifications. Transmit 12-Lead EKGs to the receiving facility if able.

title: On-Scene Physician / Transfer of Care
content:
On-Scene Physician & Transfer of Care

On-Scene Physician

Do not accept orders from an on-scene physician without OLMC approval. If a controversy arises, contact OLMC for a direct discussion between OLMC and the on-scene physician.

Transfer of Care from ALS to BLS

To preserve ALS capabilities, ALS personnel may assess a patient and, with OLMC concurrence, deem them suitable for transport by a BLS unit if the patient's condition is not expected to deteriorate or require ALS interventions.

title: Transport
content:
Transport Guidelines

Exigent Transport

In unusual circumstances where life, limb, or eyesight is threatened by a delay in waiting for a standard ambulance, alternative transport methods (e.g., F&ES apparatus, LE vehicle) are encouraged. This is a rare situation, often in Mass Casualty or Active Threat events.

Emergency Mode of Operation

The default mode of transport is non-emergency. Emergency Mode ("Lights and Sirens") will be used only when the senior EMS clinician determines the potential time savings is potentially lifesaving.

Transport of Deceased Individuals

EMS will not transport deceased persons unless death occurs during transport or under rare circumstances (e.g., remains might be destroyed). Mortuary Affairs will coordinate transport.

title: TCCC Concepts
content:
Tactical Combat Casualty Care (TCCC) Concepts

TCCC is evidence-based trauma care that reduces mortality. Select TCCC skills and concepts have been added to trauma protocols for use in all environments, not just tactical combat.

title: Universal Precautions & Exposures
content:
Universal Precautions & Exposures

Universal Precautions

Blood and body fluid precautions will be used for ALL patients. Routinely use barrier precautions (gloves, masks, eye protection) to prevent skin and mucous-membrane exposure. Wash hands/skin surfaces immediately if contaminated. Do not recap needles.

Exposure to Blood/Body Fluids or Needle Sticks

Immediately report the event to the receiving facility upon arrival and follow local guidance and procedures set forth by Infection Control.

title: Additions to National Scope of Practice Model
content:
Additions to National Scope of Practice Model

The following skills are authorized for use following verification by the local Medical Director.

Skill Level 1 - EMR and above

  • Nasopharyngeal Airway (NPA) Insertion
  • High-Flow Nasal Cannula
  • Blood Glucose Testing
  • Oral Glucose Administration

Skill Level 2 - NREMT and above

  • Supraglottic Airway (SGA) Insertion
  • Capnometry
  • Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
  • Needle Thoracentesis (must maintain TCCC Tier 2+)
  • 12-Lead Acquisition / Cardiac Monitoring

Skill Level 3 - 68W, 4N0X1, & AEMT

  • Suction of Advanced Airway
  • Blood/Fluid Warmer
  • Infusion Pump
  • Medication Administration: Controlled Substances for Pain, Dexamethasone, etc.

title: Air Force EMS Personnel Specific Information
content:
Air Force EMS Personnel Specific Information

Protocols may address the use of equipment not currently possessed by an EMS agency. All ambulance transport agencies operating under an AF Medical Director must possess the mandatory equipment outlined in the Minimum Ambulance Stock List.

5-level 4N0X1 EMTs/NRPs assigned to prehospital response are authorized to administer intravenous medications according to protocol, following completion of the USAF Medication Administration Course.

title: A-1: Trauma Center / Air Ambulance Criteria
content:
Trauma Center Criteria (CDC)

Based on the CDC Guidelines for Field Triage of Injured Patients.

Step One: Vitals & LOC

  • Glasgow Coma Scale ≤ 13
  • Systolic Blood Pressure < 90 mmHg
  • Respiratory Rate < 10 or > 29 breaths/min (< 20 in infant) or need for ventilatory support

→ If Yes to any, transport to highest level trauma center.

Step Two: Anatomy of Injury

  • All penetrating injuries to head, neck, torso, and extremities proximal to elbow or knees
  • Chest wall instability or deformity (e.g., flail chest)
  • Two or more proximal long-bone fractures
  • Crushed, degloved, mangled, or pulseless extremity
  • Amputation proximal to wrist or ankle
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Open or depressed skull fracture
  • Paralysis

→ If Yes to any, transport to highest level trauma center.

Step Three: Mechanism of Injury

  • Falls: Adults > 20 feet; Children > 10 feet or 2-3x child's height
  • High-Risk Auto Crash: Intrusion > 12 in. occupant site, > 18 in. any site; Ejection (partial or complete); Death in same passenger compartment
  • Auto vs. pedestrian/bicyclist thrown, run over, or with significant (>20 mph) impact
  • Motorcycle crash > 20 mph

→ If Yes to any, transport to a trauma center.

Step Four: Special Considerations

  • Older adults (> 55 years)
  • Children should be triaged preferentially to pediatric-capable trauma centers
  • Anticoagulants and bleeding disorders
  • Burns (with trauma mechanism, triage to trauma center)
  • Pregnancy > 20 weeks
  • EMS provider judgment

→ If Yes, transport to a trauma center or hospital capable of managing serious injuries. Consider OLMC consultation.

When in doubt, transport to a trauma center.

title: A-2: Care of Minors
content:
Consent & Implied Consent

  • Care of Minors: Generally, any patient under 18.
  • Parent/Guardian Consent: Must be given for evaluation, treatment, and transport of a non-emancipated minor for non-life-threatening conditions. If unable to reach or they refuse, contact OLMC.
  • Emancipated Minors: Consent not required. Must show proof. Includes military members < 18, financially self-supporting, or declared by court.
  • Implied Consent: Applies when consent isn't given, but a reasonable person would expect it (e.g., life-threatening condition where patient/guardian lacks capacity).

Abuse & Neglect (Mandatory Reporting)

  • Child abuse is physical/mental injury, sexual abuse, or negligent treatment of a child < 18.
  • Suspected Abuse/Neglect: Suspect if injury/illness is inconsistent with history. Document psychological signs (passivity, fear, aggression) and physical signs (unexplained bruises, burns, poor hygiene, malnutrition).
  • Contact OLMC for immediate reporting. Contact LE for protective custody.

Sexual Assault (Mandatory Reporting)

  • Document signs like pain/itching/bleeding in genital area.
  • Contact OLMC for immediate reporting. This is a legal requirement.
  • Care: Address only life threats to avoid destroying evidence. Place clothing in paper bags. Collect bodily fluids if possible.
  • Transport to a facility capable of pediatric sexual assault examinations.

title: A-3: Care of Adults
content:
Consent & Implied Consent

  • Consent: Must be given for evaluation, treatment, and transport for non-life-threatening conditions.
  • Capacity: Patient must be alert and oriented, GCS 15, understand their condition, and verbalize risks/benefits.
  • Implied Consent: Applies in life-threatening conditions where patient lacks capacity.
  • Legal Incompetence: If a court appointed a guardian, they must consent unless implied consent applies.

Elder/Incompetent Patient Abuse & Neglect

  • Suspect if injury/illness is inconsistent with history. Document psychological and physical signs.
  • Contact OLMC for immediate reporting (Family Advocacy, Adult Protective Services, LE).

Domestic Violence

  • Be aware of state/federal reporting laws (often required for firearm injuries, rape, stabbings).
  • Ensure scene safety. Contact LE as needed.

Sexual Assault

  • Address only life threats to avoid destroying evidence.
  • Place clothing in paper bags. Collect bodily fluids if possible.
  • LE should secure the scene. Transport to a facility capable of sexual assault examinations.
  • Contacting law enforcement is at the discretion of the adult patient.

title: A-4: Patient Refusal / AMA & Active Duty Considerations
content:
Refusal Guidelines

  • Adults & Emancipated Minors: May accept refusal if patient is A&O x4, GCS 15, and demonstrates capacity (understands risks, benefits, consequences).
  • Children (<18, not emancipated): Must obtain parental/guardian consent for refusal.
  • If a patient with a life-threatening condition refuses, contact OLMC immediately.
  • For any refusal against medical advice (AMA), contact OLMC to speak with the patient. Document the release as "Against Medical Advice", obtain patient and witness signatures.

Special Considerations

  • SI/HI: For patients endorsing suicidal/homicidal ideation who refuse transport, contact OLMC and LE to discuss detention for evaluation.
  • Military Service Members: Contact OLMC. Consider contacting the patient's Commander or First Sergeant.
  • Diabetics: Patient must meet ALL criteria to refuse: Hx of insulin-dependent DM, no oral hypoglycemics/long-acting insulin in 24 hrs, return to baseline mental status after Dextrose, BGL <60 pre-treatment and >100 post-treatment, can eat, has follow-up, normal VS, and a competent adult supervisor is present.
  • Overdose: If naloxone is given and patient recovers and refuses, contact OLMC. Patient must be left with a competent adult supervisor.

title: A-5: Combative Patients & Law Enforcement Restraint
content:
Combative Patients

  • Ensure scene safety. LE should assist with physical restraint.
  • Use soft restraints. Never place patient prone (face down).
  • If chemical restraints are used, apply physical restraints once sedated.

Law Enforcement (LE) Restrained Patients

  • An officer must remain present. If transported with LE restraints, an officer with a key must accompany the patient in the ambulance.
  • Handcuffs should be in front or on side rails.
  • If not under arrest, transition to soft restraints if possible.

Conducted Electrical Weapon (CEW) / Taser® Probe Removal

  • Performed by SL2 or higher. Probes may be evidence. LE should remove if possible.
  • Contraindications for EMS removal: Probes in face, above clavicles, breast, groin, or hand; or embedded in a vessel, joint, or bone.
  • Procedure:
    1. Ensure PPE and that probe wires are disconnected.
    2. Stabilize skin. Grasp probe by metal body.
    3. Remove in a single quick motion.
    4. Ensure probe is intact. Clean wound and apply dressing.
    5. Dispose of as sharps hazard if not evidence.
    6. If not easily extracted, leave in place and transport.

title: A-6: Field Termination / Non-Initiation of CPR
content:
Non-Initiation of Resuscitation

Contact OLMC immediately to discuss non-initiation if any of the following are present:

Universal Criteria (SL 1-5)

  • Situations where CPR would place rescuers at risk.
  • Patient presentation incompatible with life (rigor mortis, decapitation, dependent lividity, decomposition).
  • A valid Advanced Directive (AD) or Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) order is present.

Traumatic Non-Initiation Criteria (SL 1-5)

  • Injuries incompatible with life (decapitation, transection, incineration).
  • Blunt/penetrating trauma with evidence of prolonged cardiac arrest.
  • Penetrating trauma, absent signs of life, and found in asystole.
  • Cardiac arrest secondary to blunt trauma with no organized cardiac rhythm.

Field Termination Criteria

BLS Termination - Medical Arrest (ALL CRITERIA MUST BE MET)

  • Unwitnessed Arrest.
  • Airway effectively managed.
  • At least 20 minutes of high-quality CPR performed.
  • 3 AED analyses without shock advised.
  • BGL > 60 mg/dL.
  • EtCO2 < 10 mmHg despite effective CPR.
  • Medical Control approves termination.

BLS Termination - Traumatic Arrest (ALL CRITERIA MUST BE MET)

  • Airway effectively managed.
  • 10 minutes of high-quality CPR without ROSC.
  • 2 AED analyses without shock advised.
  • Bilateral needle decompression performed (SL2+) without improvement.
  • BGL > 60 mg/dL.
  • Medical Control approves termination.

Additional ALS Criteria (SL 4-5)

  • Rhythm has remained asystole or PEA for at least the last 10 minutes of resuscitation.

Resuscitation should NOT be terminated for pregnant women with a potentially viable fetus (>20 weeks) without OLMC contact.

title: B-1: General Patient Care / Monitoring & Vascular Access
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Treat all patients with respect; ensure scene/crew safety, BSI/PPE precautions.
  • Request ALS/additional resources as needed. Consult On-Line Medical Control (OLMC) as needed.
  • Establish Level of Consciousness (LOC), manage Immediate Life Threats.
  • Complete initial assessment/patient history/physical exam. Treat illness/injury IAW applicable protocol.
  • B-2, Airway Management. Oxygen - Titrate SpO2 ≥ 94%.
  • Patient Monitoring / Vital Signs: Obtain initial HR, RR, BP, SpO2, Pain.
  • Blood Glucose Level (BGL): Obtain as patient condition or protocol requires.
  • Carbon Monoxide (SpCO): Monitor CO (if available) if suspected CO exposure.
  • Transport to the most appropriate facility based on chief complaint.
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry): Monitor (if equipped) for all AMS/lethargy, hypotension, SOB, trauma, or cardiac arrest.
  • Cardiac Monitoring: Monitor (if equipped) for all AMS/lethargy, CP/SOB, trauma, or cardiac arrest.
SL 3+
  • 12-Lead EKG: If indicated/equipped, obtain 12-Lead/q 10 min serial EKGs (PRN) and transmit if able.
  • Vascular Access: As needed per protocol. IV Access (Saline Lock), IO Access if needed.
  • Infuse fluids with a pressure infusion bag.
  • Blood/Fluid Warmers: use for all Trauma/Hypovolemia & Hypothermic patients, if available.

Additional Considerations

  • Patient care should be a team effort by all personnel on-scene.
  • Every patient evaluated by EMS must have a patient care report (PCR) completed.
  • Record Vital Signs (minimum of 2 sets): CRITICAL patient q 5 min; NON-CRITICAL q 15 mins.

title: B-2: Airway Management
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Open, Assess, Clear Airway - Finger sweeps (not blind), head-tilt/chin-lift or jaw thrust.
  • If obstructed, perform Abdominal or Chest thrusts.
  • Suction Oral/nasal suction PRN.
  • BVM Ventilations - Adult normal rate 12-20, assist ventilations <10 and >30.
  • NPA/OPA - Insert appropriate size as indicated.
  • Oxygen - Titrate to SpO2 ≥ 94%.
  • High Flow Nasal Cannula - 15-25 LPM NC if SpO2 < 85%, 10 min max.
SL 2+
  • Supraglottic Airway (SGA) - Insert SGA as needed (PRIMARY for Cardiac Arrest).
  • Suction of advanced airway.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) - For any lethargic, altered, hypotensive patient or with SGA.
  • Needle Thoracentesis - Suspected tension pneumothorax (Lateral site preferred). SL2/3 w/ TCCC Tier 2+ and OLMC approval.
SL 3+
  • PEEP Valve - Use w/BVM for hypoxia despite O2/Airway, begin 5cmH2O, titrate to 10cmH2O max.
  • CPAP - If no contraindications initiate at 5cmH20 w/severe respiratory distress.
  • Gastric Decompression - Insert OG tube after advanced airway placement.
SL 4+
  • BiLevel CPAP (BiPAP) - If equipped, for severe respiratory distress.
  • USAF NRPs Only: ETI via video or direct laryngoscopy if concerns for airway burns or if SGA ineffective.
  • Cricothyrotomy - EMERGENCY means to secure airway if SGA ineffective or required by pt condition.
  • Foreign body removal - Utilize Magill forceps under direct visualization.
  • EtCO2 (Capnography) monitoring.
  • Post-Advanced Airway Sedation and Pain Control (Ketamine, Midazolam, Fentanyl).

title: B-3: Nausea & Vomiting
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Place in position of comfort, provide verbal reassurance.
  • For Nausea: Inhale Alcohol Pad vapor x 3 min, repeat PRN.
  • BGL - If <60mg/dL or >300mg/dL, see B-20, Diabetic Emergencies.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - Administer fluids per B-29, Shock/Hypotension.
  • Ondansetron 4mg IV/IO or ODT PO, repeat x 1 in 15-20 min PRN, max dose 8mg.
SL 4+
  • If Ondansetron is ineffective: Metoclopramide 5-10mg in 100mL NS IV/IO.
  • For dystonia/akathisia from Metoclopramide: Diphenhydramine 25 mg IV/IO.

title: B-4: Pain Management
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Determine pain score using DVPRS or Wong-Baker.
  • Place in position of comfort, apply ice packs/splints.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - Administer fluids per B-29, Shock/Hypotension.
  • Monitor V/S & EtCO2 for controlled substances.
  • MILD Pain: Acetaminophen 1000mg PO AND/OR Meloxicam 15mg PO.
  • MODERATE to SEVERE Pain (SBP > 100mmHg): Fentanyl 400mcg OTFC buccal OR 100mcg IN.
  • MODERATE to SEVERE Pain: Ketamine 50mg IN, repeat q 20 min PRN.
  • Opioid Reversal: Naloxone (slow or emergent dosing available).
SL 4+
  • MODERATE to SEVERE Pain:
    • Any SBP: Ketamine 0.2 mg/kg IV/IO or 0.5mg/kg IM/IN.
    • SBP > 100mmHg: Fentanyl 1mcg/kg IV/IO/IN/IM (100mcg max single dose).

title: B-5: Cardiac Arrest
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Establish pulselessness/apnea; call for ALS/additional resources.
  • Evaluate for non-initiation/termination criteria per A-6.
  • Initiate high-quality CPR (30:2) / Apply AED, follow prompts.
  • Airway: BVM with 100% O2, place NPA and OPA. See B-2, Airway Management.
  • Suspected Overdose: Naloxone 4mg IN, repeat q 2-3 min PRN.
  • Assess for Hypothermia & BGL.
  • For ROSC: see B-6, ROSC.
  • After 20 min of high-quality CPR, contact OLMC to discuss termination.
SL 2+
  • Capnometry (in line with BVM or SGA) - Maintain > 10mmHg.
  • Supraglottic Airway (SGA) - As soon as possible.
  • Needle Thoracentesis - Bilateral for suspected tension pneumothorax (with OLMC approval for SL2/3).
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: Establish ASAP.
  • Immediately after access - Epinephrine (1mg/10mL) 1mg IV/IO, then q 3-5 min.
  • Hypovolemia - LR 1000mL bolus, may repeat x 1 PRN.
  • BGL < 60mg/dL: Dextrose 10% (D10W), 250mL IV/IO over 2 min.
SL 4+
  • VF/Pulseless VT: Defibrillate at 200J (biphasic).
  • After first shock & Epi: Amiodarone 300mg IV/IO, then 150mg IV/IO.
  • Torsades de Pointes: Magnesium Sulfate 2g in 10mL NS IV/IO.
  • Hyperkalemia: Calcium Gluconate 2g IV/IO, Sodium Bicarbonate 100mEq IV/IO, Albuterol 15mg Nebulized.

Additional Considerations (Hs & Ts)

  • Hypovolemia, Hypoxia, Hydrogen ion (acidosis), Hypo/Hyperkalemia, Hypothermia
  • Tension Pneumothorax, Tamponade (cardiac), Toxins, Thrombosis (pulmonary), Thrombosis (coronary)

title: B-6: ROSC & Post-Arrest Care
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Treat underlying Hs & Ts.
  • Assess/treat for Hypothermia.
  • Check BGL.
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) - Continuous monitoring.
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG - Obtain serial EKGs.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - Ensure IV/IO x2.
  • If SBP < 90mmHg: 500mL LR IV/IO bolus, may repeat x3 PRN.
SL 4+
  • Persistent Hypotension: Consider Push Dose Epinephrine as bridge to Norepinephrine drip 2-12mcg/min.
  • If refractory, Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO.
  • For post-arrest VT/VF: Amiodarone 150mg IV/IO over 10 min, then drip.

title: B-7: Bradycardia
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

Unstable (CHAPS): Chest Pain, Hypotension, Altered Mental Status, Pulmonary Edema, Signs of Shock.

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen.
  • Check BGL.
  • If overdose suspected, see B-24.
SL 2+
  • Asymptomatic: Closely monitor, no intervention required.
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) if lethargic/altered/hypotensive.
SL 4+
  • Stable and Symptomatic: Atropine 1mg IV/IO; repeat q 3-5 min PRN; max 3mg.
  • Unstable and Symptomatic: Transcutaneously Pace at HR 70. Consider sedation (Ketamine or Midazolam).
  • Refractory Bradycardia: Epinephrine Drip 2-10mcg/min or Norepinephrine Drip 2-12mcg/min.

title: B-8: Tachycardia, Narrow Complex
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

Unstable (CHAPS): Chest Pain, Hypotension, Altered Mental Status, Pulmonary Edema, Signs of Shock.

SL 2+
  • Asymptomatic: Closely monitor.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry).
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
SL 4+
  • Unstable and Symptomatic: Synchronized Cardiovert. Regular rhythm: 50-100J. Irregular rhythm: 120-200J. Consider sedation.
  • Stable and Symptomatic (HR >= 150):
    • Vagal Maneuvers.
    • Adenosine 6mg rapid IV/IO push, then 12mg if no conversion.
    • If no conversion, contact OLMC for Metoprolol 5mg IV/IO.

title: B-9: Tachycardia, Wide Complex
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

Unstable (CHAPS): Chest Pain, Hypotension, Altered Mental Status, Pulmonary Edema, Signs of Shock.

SL 4+
  • Polymorphic (Torsades de Pointes): If pulseless, begin CPR. If pulse present, Magnesium 2g in 10mL NS IV/IO over 2-3 min.
  • Stable & Asymptomatic (Regular/Monomorphic):
    • Adenosine 6mg then 12mg rapid IV/IO push.
    • If not effective: Amiodarone 150mg IV/IO in 100mL NS over 10 min. Repeat if needed.
  • Unstable & Symptomatic: Synchronized Cardiovert. Wide Regular: 100J. Wide Irregular: 120-200J.
  • If rhythm converts, give Amiodarone 150mg IV/IO over 10 min.

title: B-10: Chest Pain
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Keep patient in position of comfort.
  • Aspirin 324mg (four 81mg tablets) chewed.
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
  • If SBP ≥ 100mmHg, assist with patient's prescribed Nitroglycerin.
  • NTG Contraindicated: Right-Sided MI, SBP < 100, Viagra/Levitra in 24 hrs, Cialis in 48 hrs.
  • Transport to PCI capable facility; scene time < 10 min.
SL 4+
  • Pain Management:
    • Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL q 3-5 min PRN if SBP > 100mmHg.
    • Pain unresolved by NTG (if SBP > 100mmHg): Fentanyl 50-100mcg IV/IO.
  • If Chest Pain from suspected stimulant abuse (HTN & Tachycardia > 120): Midazolam 2.5-5mg IV/IO/IN/IM.

title: B-11: Difficulty Breathing - Asthma / COPD
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • E-2, Airway Management. Ventilate at 6-8 breaths/min if required.
  • Severe Asthma: Assist with patient's prescribed Epinephrine Autoinjector 0.3mg IM.
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) monitoring.
SL 3+
  • Wheezing/Respiratory Distress:
    • Albuterol 2.5mg/2.5mL nebulized, repeat PRN.
    • Ipratropium Bromide 0.5mg/3mL nebulized, repeat PRN (max 1.5mg).
  • Severe distress with no improvement: Epinephrine Autoinjector 0.3mg IM.
  • Consider CPAP.
SL 4+
  • Audible wheezing/distress: Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO/IM/PO.
  • If unimproved: Epinephrine (1mg/mL) 0.3mg IM, Magnesium Sulfate 2g IV/IO, Ketamine 0.2 mg/kg slow IV.
  • If still no improvement, consider Epinephrine Drip 2-10mcg/min IV/IO.

title: B-12: Difficulty Breathing - CHF / Pulmonary Edema
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen.
  • If chest pain, see B-10.
SL 2+
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry).
SL 3+
  • Consider CPAP.
  • If using BVM, consider PEEP Valve.
  • Vascular Access.
  • SBP > 100mmHg: Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL; repeat q 5 min PRN.
SL 4+
  • Consider BiLevel CPAP (BiPAP).
  • SBP < 90mmHg despite Fluid Bolus: Norepinephrine 2-12mcg/min IV/IO.

title: B-13: Stroke / CVA
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Establish onset of symptoms (last known well time).
  • Check BGL. If <60mg/dL, treat per B-20.
  • Perform Cincinnati Pre-Hospital Stroke Scale (CPSS).
  • Minimize scene time to < 10 min.
  • If CPSS positive & onset < 6 hours: Initiate "Stroke Alert", transport to Primary Stroke Center.
  • If SBP > 110mmHg: Elevate head of stretcher 15-30°.
SL 2+
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - Large bore IVs.
  • Perform Large Vessel Occlusion (LVO) VAN Stroke Exam.
  • If LVO positive & onset > 6 hrs but < 24 hrs: Transport to Comprehensive Stroke Center.
  • Hypertension should NOT be treated in possible CVA patients.
  • If Hypotensive, see B-29.

Additional Considerations

  • "Last Known Well Time" is critically important as it determines treatment options.
  • Minor, rapidly improving, or resolved symptoms could indicate a TIA and require transport and evaluation.
  • Stroke mimics include postictal states (after seizures) and Bell's Palsy. When in doubt, activate a Stroke Alert.

title: B-14: Airborne Pathogens (COVID, etc.)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Ensure proper PPE (N95, Eye/Face protection, gown, gloves).
  • Limit exposed responders. Apply surgical mask to patient.
  • Airway Management: Use HEPA filter on BVM. Place surgical mask over NC or NRB.
  • Wheezing/Distress: Do NOT use nebulizer unless HEPA filter can be attached to exhaust. Use MDI with spacer instead.

title: B-15: Abdominal Pain
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Check BGL. Treat per B-20 if indicated.
  • Nausea/Vomiting: See B-3.
SL 2+
  • 12-Lead EKG and Cardiac Monitoring as clinically indicated.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access if hypotensive (see B-29).
  • Pain Management: See B-4.

Additional Considerations

  • Consider cardiac etiology in patients >50yo, diabetics, and females with upper abdominal complaints.
  • Abdominal pain in females of childbearing age should be treated as an ectopic pregnancy until proven otherwise.
  • Consider Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) in patients >50yo with abdominal/flank/back pain.

title: B-16: Altered Mental Status
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Crew/responder safety is main priority. See B-18 for restraints.
  • Check pupillary response, treat suspected overdose (B-24).
  • Check BGL (B-20). If no improvement, perform stroke screen (B-13).
  • Check for signs of Seizure (B-28), Hyperthermia (B-22), Hypothermia (B-23), or Head Trauma (C-6).
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry).
  • Cardiac Monitor & 12-Lead EKG.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access.
  • Check for signs of Sepsis (B-27).

Additional Considerations: AEIOU-TIPS

Acidosis/Alcohol, Epilepsy/Electrolytes, Infection, Overdose, Uremia, Trauma/Tumor, Insulin, Psychosis/Poisoning, Stroke/Shock/Seizure.

title: B-17: Anaphylaxis & Allergic Reaction
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management. Apply cold pack to insect bite/sting.
  • Moderate/Severe Reaction: Assist with patient's prescribed Epinephrine Autoinjector 0.3mg IM.
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) and Cardiac Monitoring.
SL 3+
  • Moderate/Severe: Administer agency Epinephrine Autoinjector 0.3mg IM.
  • Wheezing/Distress: Albuterol & Ipratropium Bromide nebulized.
  • Vascular Access.
  • Mild Reaction: Diphenhydramine 25mg IV/IO/IM.
  • Moderate/Severe Reaction: Diphenhydramine 50mg IV/IO/IM.
SL 4+
  • Moderate/Severe: Epinephrine (1mg/1mL) 0.3mg IM if not given. Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO/IM/PO.
  • Unresponsive to above & patient on beta-blockers: consider Glucagon 1mg slow IV push.
  • If hypotensive despite above: Epinephrine Drip 2-10mcg/min IV/IO.

title: B-18: Behavioral Emergencies
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Stage until scene is safe.
  • Physical Restraint If Indicated: Use soft restraints. Never keep patient prone.
  • Check BGL. See overdose protocol if indicated.
SL 4+
  • Combative patients (Chemical Restraint):
    • Ketamine 4mg/kg IM x 1 OR
    • Midazolam 10mg IM/IN x 1 OR 5mg IV/IO x 1.
    • (Reduce Midazolam dose for patients >= 65 yrs).
  • Cardiac monitoring and capnography required for all sedated patients.

title: B-19: Bites and Envenomations
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Identify source of bite/envenomation if able.
  • Provide general wound care/irrigation. Immobilize the injury.
  • Spider/Scorpion/Bee/Wasp: Remove stinger if present.
  • Snake Bite: Outline margin of swelling/redness and note time. DO NOT apply ice.
  • Jellyfish/Man-O-War: Lift tentacles away. Wash with sea water or vinegar for >= 30 seconds. DO NOT use fresh water.
  • Stingray/Lion Fish: Splint barbs in place, do not remove.
SL 4+
  • Spider/Scorpion Bite with severe muscle spasms (SBP > 100): Midazolam 2.5mg IV/IO/IM/IN.

title: B-20: Diabetic Emergencies
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • BGL < 60mg/dL & can swallow: Oral Glucose 15g PO, repeat x 1 in 10 min PRN.
SL 3+
  • BGL < 60mg/dL & unable to swallow/AMS: Dextrose 10% (D10W) 250mL IV/IO, repeat x 1 PRN.
  • BGL < 60mg/dL & no IV/IO access: Glucagon 1-2mg IM, repeat x 1 in 15 min PRN.
  • BGL > 300mg/dL: LR 1000mL bolus, repeat x 1 PRN.

title: B-21: Hypertension (Non-Pregnant)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Asymptomatic HTN: No intervention required, supportive care.
SL 2+
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
  • Transport with head of gurney raised to 30°.

Additional Considerations

Aggressive treatment of HTN increases mortality. Most patients require only supportive care. Hypertensive Emergency is typically defined as SBP > 220 or DBP > 120 AND signs of end organ damage (AMS, Chest Pain, Stroke-like Sx).

title: B-22: Hyperthermia / Heat Injuries
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Move patient to a cool environment.
  • Encourage PO fluids if tolerated.
  • Heat Exhaustion or Heat Stroke: Initiate active cooling measures (ice sheets, misting, ice packs to neck/axilla/groin).
  • STOP active cooling when temperature reaches 102°F.
  • Check BGL.
SL 4+
  • If shivering occurs during cooling: Midazolam 2.5mg IV/IO or 5mg IM/IN.

title: B-23: Hypothermia / Cold Injuries
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Handle patient gently, maintain horizontal position.
  • Remove wet clothing.
  • Passive Warming (Core temp > 90°F): Warm/reflective blankets, cover head.
  • Active Warming (Core temp < 90°F): Heat packs in armpit/groin (not directly on skin).

Additional Considerations

  • Cardiac Arrest: Pulse should be assessed for 60 seconds if not on monitor.
  • Do NOT administer IV cardiac medications if core temp < 86°F.
  • Limit defibrillation to 3 attempts if core temp < 86°F.

title: B-24: Overdose / Toxic Ingestion
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Contact Poison Control (1-800-222-1222).
  • Suspected Opioid Overdose/AMS or RR < 8: Naloxone Nasal Spray 4mg IN.
  • Check for analgesic patches. If seizure, see B-28.
SL 4+
  • Suspected Dystonic Reaction: Diphenhydramine 25mg IV.
  • Suspected Tricyclic Antidepressant Overdose (QRS > 0.12s): Sodium Bicarbonate 100mEq IV/IO.
  • Suspected Beta Blocker/Calcium Channel Blocker Overdose (bradycardic): Calcium Gluconate 2g IV/IO AND Glucagon 3mg IV/IO.
  • Cocaine/Amphetamine OD with Agitation: Midazolam 2.5-5mg IM/IN/IV/IO.

title: B-25: Renal Failure / Dialysis
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Check BGL.
SL 2+
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
SL 3+
  • If past scheduled dialysis w/AMS, suspect hyperkalemia: Albuterol 5mg Nebulized, repeat x 3 PRN.
SL 4+
  • If evidence of Hyperkalemia with EKG changes: Continue Albuterol AND give Calcium Gluconate 2g slow IV/IO AND Sodium Bicarbonate 100mEq IV/IO.

Additional Considerations

ALWAYS consider hyperkalemia. Do not start an IV or take a BP in an extremity with a shunt/fistula.

title: B-26: Drowning / Submersion
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Suction PRN; DO NOT waste time suctioning unless water/emesis visible.
  • Conscious: Oxygen PRN, SpO2 > 94%. Consider CPAP.
  • Conscious with AMS: 5 assisted breaths via BVM.
  • Unresponsive: 5 breaths via BVM. If pulse, ventilate 1 breath q 5-6 seconds. If no pulse, start CPR (B-5).
  • Remove wet clothing; dry/warm patient.

title: B-27: Sepsis / Septic Shock
content:
Sepsis Guidelines

Suspected or known infection, EtCO2 < 26 AND 2 or more of the following:

  • Temp < 96.0°F or > 100.4°F
  • HR > 90 AND RR > 20
  • SBP < 90 mmHg
  • Altered Mental Status (GCS < 15)

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - IV/IO x 2.
  • Fluid Admin: LR 500mL IV/IO Bolus to maintain SBP ≥ 90mmHg, repeat PRN to max 2L.
  • Temp > 100.4°F: Acetaminophen 1000mg PO.
SL 4+
  • If hypotension remains despite fluids: Consider Push Dose Epinephrine as bridge to Norepinephrine Drip 2-12mcg/min.
  • If no improvement (refractory shock): Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO.

title: B-28: Seizures (Non-Pregnant)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Place in Supine or Recovery Position.
  • Check BGL.
SL 4+
  • Actively Seizing Patient:
    • Midazolam 5mg IV/IO, repeat x 1 in 5 min PRN, OR
    • Midazolam 10mg IN/IM x 1.

title: B-29: Shock / Hypotension (Non-Trauma)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 3+
  • Vascular Access - IV/IO x 2.
  • Hypotension (SBP < 90):
    • Hypovolemic, Septic, Neurogenic, Anaphylactic: LR 500mL IV/IO, repeat PRN to max 2000mL.
    • Cardiogenic: LR 250mL IV/IO, repeat PRN to max 1000mL.
SL 4+
  • Condition unchanged after fluid: Consider Push Dose Epinephrine as bridge to Norepinephrine drip 2-12mcg/min.
  • If refractory to fluids/pressors: Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO.

title: B-30: Syncope/ Dizziness / Weakness
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Consider need for Spinal Motion Restriction (C-7).
  • Treat injuries per C-1, Trauma.
  • Check BGL.
SL 2+
  • Perform Cincinnati Pre-Hospital Stroke Scale (CPSS).
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access if SBP < 90mmHg.
  • HR > 100bpm with normal SBP: LR 500mL IV/IO fluid bolus, repeat x 2 PRN.
SL 4+
  • Perform VAN LVO Assessment.
  • Treat dysrhythmias per applicable protocol.

title: B-31: Medical Support Apparatus
content:
Key Concepts

EMS may encounter medically complex patients with devices like tracheostomies, home ventilators, chest drains, Ventricular Assist Devices (VADs), defibrillator vests, indwelling catheters, dialysis fistulas, feeding tubes, etc.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

  • Tracheostomies: If dislodged, ask caregiver to reinsert if able. Otherwise, ventilate with infant mask over stoma.
  • Home Ventilators: If malfunctioning, immediately transition to BVM.
  • Chest Drains: If dislodged, cover tract with occlusive dressing. Watch for tension pneumothorax.
  • Ventricular Assist Devices (VADs): Central/peripheral pulses may not be felt. Use skin color, temp, LOC to assess perfusion. MAP from monitor is key (usual range 70-90mmHg). CPR may be performed but risks displacement. Contact VAD coordinator.
  • Defibrillator Vests: If patient is critical or has been shocked, remove vest and apply monitor pads.
  • Indwelling Catheters (PICC, Hickman, etc.): SL 4/5 may access per B-1. If dislodged, cover site and control bleeding.
  • Dialysis Fistulas/Grafts: Assess for "thrill". Control bleeding with direct pressure. DO NOT use TQ unless direct pressure fails. Access only in pulseless/peri-arrest patients (SL 4/5).

title: C-1: Trauma, General
content:
Key Concepts: MARCH-PAWS

  • M – Massive hemorrhage
  • A – Airway / AVPU
  • R – Respiration
  • C – Circulation
  • H – Hypothermia/Head Injury
  • ---
  • P – Pain
  • A – Antibiotics
  • W – Wounds
  • S – Splints

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Perform triage / life-saving interventions.
  • Massive Hemorrhage: Apply approved TQs / hemostatic dressings & pressure dressing.
  • Airway: B-2, Airway Management & Assess Mental Status (AVPU).
  • Respirations: Place occlusive dressings on penetrating chest/abdominal wounds.
  • Circulation: Re-check TQ placement, assess HR, BP, SpO2.
  • Hypothermia: Remove wet clothing; utilize blankets, HPMK.
  • Head Injury: Elevate head of cot 30°. See C-6, Head Injuries.
  • Pain: Position of comfort if no spinal motion restrictions.
  • Wounds: Secure penetrating objects, cover exposed injuries.
  • Splint: Joints above and below suspected fracture; check CSM.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: 2 large bore IVs or IOs as needed.
  • Life threatening hemorrhage within 3 hrs of injury: Tranexamic Acid (TXA) 2g IV/IO over 1 min.
  • Fluid Resuscitation:
    • WITH Head Injury: LR minimum volume IV/IO to SBP 110mmHg.
    • WITHOUT Head Injury: LR minimum volume IV/IO to SBP 80-90mmHg.
  • Antibiotics: Open wounds and >60 min transport: Ertapenem (Invanz) 1g IV/IO.

title: C-2: Burns, General
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • STOP the burning process. Treat trauma/life threats first.
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen.
  • Remove constricting items (rings, watches). Estimate burn size.
  • Thermal Burn: <10% TBSA irrigate with water/saline, cover with dry sterile dressing. >10% TBSA cover with burn sheet.
  • Chemical Burn: Brush off powder, remove clothing, flush with water/saline for at least 15 mins.
  • Electrical/Lightning: Ensure scene safety. Identify entrance/exit points. If cardiac arrest, see B-5.
  • Monitor distal pulses in circumferentially burned limbs. Keep patient warm.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: If >20% TBSA 2nd/3rd degree burns, initiate 2 large bore IVs or IOs.
  • Fluid Resuscitation (>20% TBSA): Use ISR Rule of 10s. Start adults at 300mL/hr until calculated.
    • 40-80kg patient: %TBSA x 10mL/hr = fluid rate.
    • For every 10kg over 80kg, increase rate by 100mL/hr.
SL 4+
  • If suspected inhalation injury, perform early airway management. Consider ETI/Cricothyrotomy.
  • Maintain sedation/analgesia post-airway insertion.

title: C-3: Crush Injuries
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Control hemorrhage, B-2 Airway/Oxygen.
  • If extremity compressed for ≥ 2 hours: Apply TWO Tourniquets above the injury BEFORE pressure is released.
  • Prevent/Treat Hypothermia.
SL 2+
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) and Cardiac Monitoring.
SL 3+
  • If extremity compressed for ≥ 2 hours, BEFORE release:
    • Vascular Access x 2 large bore IVs or IO.
    • Begin bolus of LR 2000mL IV/IO.
    • After bolus, begin maintenance infusion of LR 1000 mL/hr.
  • After release, monitor for compartment syndrome (6 P's). Pain Management per B-4.
SL 4+
  • Dysrhythmias likely secondary to hyperkalemia; if present administer:
    • Calcium Gluconate 2g IV/IO.
    • Sodium Bicarbonate 8.4% 100mEq IV/IO.
    • Albuterol 5mg nebulized.

title: C-4: Epistaxis
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • If actively bleeding: Provide direct pressure by pinching the anterior portion of the nose with moderate force for 5 - 10 min continuously (tilt head forward).
  • If unable to stop bleeding, have patient blow nose to remove clots and reapply pressure.
  • Ensure suction is available for posterior bleeds draining into oropharynx.
SL 3+
  • If bleeding continues despite pressure: Oxymetazoline (Afrin) 2 sprays in affected nare(s).
  • Establish vascular access for significant/uncontrolled bleeding.

Additional Considerations

Encourage patients to spit out blood to prevent nausea & vomiting. 90% of nosebleeds are anterior and non-life-threatening. Posterior bleeds are difficult to control and can be life-threatening.

title: C-5: Eye Injuries
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Perform basic visual exam.
  • Penetrating object: DO NOT remove; stabilize in place.
  • No penetrating object: Apply rigid eye shield, touching only orbital bones.
  • Extruded eyeball: Place moist, sterile dressing on top; cover with eye shield.
  • Elevate head of stretcher to 30°.
  • Eye Irrigation (for debris/chemicals, NOT penetrating injury): Irrigate with sterile water, NS, or LR. For chemicals, irrigate with at least 10L of fluid.
SL 3+
  • Chemical burns only (to facilitate irrigation): Tetracaine 0.5% 2 drops in affected eye.

title: C-6: Head/Facial Injuries
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management. NPAs should NOT be used if significant facial trauma.
  • Maintain SpO2 ≥ 93% for suspected TBI.
  • Elevate Head of stretcher 30°.
  • Avulsed Tooth: Place in milk or saline.
  • Unstable Mandible: Anticipate need for suction.
SL 2+
  • Obtain GCS. Trauma Alert for GCS < 13.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) - Target 35-40mmHg. If evidence of herniation, target 30-35mmHg.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access x2.
  • Hypotension (SBP < 110mmHg): LR minimum volume IV/IO to SBP > 110mmHg.
  • AMS or suspected herniation: Consult OLMC to discuss Hypertonic Saline 3%, 250mL IV/IO.
SL 4+
  • Consider Advanced Airway (Cricothyrotomy or ETI).
  • If hypotension persists: Norepinephrine 2-12mcg/min to maintain SBP ≥ 110mmHg.

*Evidence of Herniation

  • Cushing’s Triad: Bradycardia, Hypertension (Wide Pulse Pressure), Irregular Respirations.
  • Posturing (Decorticate/Decerebrate).
  • Rapid decline in mental status and/or unilateral pupil changes.

title: C-7: Spinal Motion Restriction (SMR)
content:
Spinal Motion Restriction Algorithm

SMR is NOT indicated for penetrating trauma to head, neck or torso.

Indications for SMR following BLUNT trauma include any of the following:

  • Acutely altered level of consciousness (e.g. GCS < 15, evidence of intoxication).
  • Midline neck or back pain and/or tenderness.
  • Focal neurologic signs and/or symptoms (e.g. numbness or motor weakness).
  • Anatomic deformity of the spine.
  • Distracting circumstances or injury (e.g. long bone fracture, degloving, or crush injuries, large burns).
  • Communication barrier (emotional/language/cognitive impairment).

Procedure if SMR is indicated:

  1. Manually stabilize the neck and back to prevent movement and place a rigid C-collar.
  2. Move the patient to the ambulance stretcher (may use Scoop device or long spine board (LSB) for extrication only).
  3. Prevent head movement with blocks/tape. Tape head and blocks in place to stretcher.
  4. Fasten stretcher seat belts.

Patients should NOT be transported on the Scoop device or LSB due to risks of tissue injury and interference with ventilation.

title: D-1: Vaginal Bleeding (Non-Postpartum)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen (target 95-100% for fetal perfusion).
  • If birth is imminent, see D-3, Childbirth/Labor.
  • Check BGL if AMS.
SL 2+
  • If patient is > 20 weeks gestation, transport in left lateral position to a facility with NICU capability if able.
  • Cardiac Monitoring & 12-Lead EKG if unstable.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) if lethargic/hypotensive.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: Two large bore IVs or IO.
  • Life-threatening bleeding: Tranexamic Acid (TXA) 1g in 10mL NS IV/IO over 10 min, repeat x1 after 30 min.
  • Hypotension (SBP < 90): LR IV/IO minimum volume to maintain SBP ≥ 90mmHg (max 2L).
SL 4+
  • Hypotension despite fluid resuscitation: Norepinephrine 2-12mcg/min IV/IO.
  • Consult OLMC for pain management.

Additional Considerations

Serious causes: Ectopic pregnancy, placental abruption (painful), placenta previa (painless, bright red), uterine rupture.

title: D-2: Seizures (Pregnant)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen (target 95-100%).
  • Place in supine or left lateral recovery position.
  • Check BGL.
SL 2+
  • Transport rapidly to facility with NICU capability. If > 20 weeks, transport left lateral.
  • Cardiac Monitoring and EKG.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry) if postictal/seizing.
SL 4+
  • Suspected eclamptic seizure: Magnesium Sulfate 4g in 100mL NS IV/IO over 10 min.
  • If no IV/IO: Magnesium Sulfate 2g IM x 1, then start IV/IO infusion.
  • If seizure continues: Midazolam 5mg IV/IO (repeat x1) OR 10mg IN/IM (x1). DO NOT stop Magnesium.
  • Status epilepticus: Magnesium Sulfate 2g in 100mL NS IV/IO over 10 min.

Additional Considerations

Preeclampsia: SBP > 140 or DBP > 90 without seizure. Eclampsia: Hypertension with seizure. Can occur up to 6 weeks postpartum. Magnesium is the definitive treatment.

title: D-3: Childbirth / Labor
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Evaluate patient. If no crowning or abnormal presentations, place in left lateral position.
  • If bleeding, see D-1, Vaginal Bleeding.
  • Imminent birth (crowning, urge to push):
    • Support baby’s head, control the delivery.
    • Check for nuchal cord. If present, slip over head or clamp and cut.
    • Deliver anterior shoulder, then posterior shoulder.
    • If baby is crying: wrap in dry blanket, place on mother's abdomen, delay clamping cord 30-60 seconds.
    • If baby is unstable: immediately clamp and cut cord. See D-5, Newborn Resuscitation.
  • Continued Care of Mother: Anticipate placenta delivery within 30 min. Do NOT pull cord. Perform fundal massage after delivery.
  • Prolapsed Umbilical Cord: Place mother in knee-to-chest position. Insert gloved hand to displace presenting part from cord. Transport immediately.
  • Shoulder Dystocia: Place mother in McRoberts Maneuver (hyperflexion of legs). Apply suprapubic pressure.
  • Breech Birth/Presenting Limb: Support presenting part. Place mother in knee-to-chest. If head fails to deliver, insert gloved hand to create airway for baby.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: 2 large bore IVs or IOs as needed.
  • After placenta delivery: Oxytocin 10 Units IM x 1 to prevent hemorrhage.
  • Life threatening bleeding: Tranexamic Acid (TXA) 1g in 10mL NS IV/IO slow push over 10 min.
  • Hypotension: LR IV/IO to maintain SBP ≥ 90mmHg.
SL 4+
  • If significant vaginal bleeding despite above: Oxytocin 20 Units in 1000mL LR; bolus 250mL, then infuse at 250mL/hr.
  • Hypotension despite fluid: Norepinephrine drip.

title: D-4: Newborn Care
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines (Birth to 24 hours)

SL 1-5
  • Assess term, tone, breathing/crying.
  • Warm, dry, and stimulate the infant. Turn ambulance heat to "high".
  • If HR < 100, not breathing adequately, limp, APGAR < 7, or meconium with weak cry, proceed to D-5, Newborn Resuscitation and call for another unit.
  • Obtain APGAR at 1 and 5 minutes. If 7-9, provide blow-by Oxygen.
  • If stable, place skin-to-skin with mother and encourage nursing.

APGAR Scoring

Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration. Scored 0, 1, or 2 for each category.

  • 10: Best possible condition
  • 7-9: Slightly depressed
  • 4-6: Moderately depressed
  • 0-3: Severely depressed

Do not delay resuscitation to obtain an APGAR score.

title: D-5: Newborn Resuscitation
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines (Birth to 24 hours)

SL 1-5
  • Preterm, decreased tone, abnormal respirations or absent cry: Clear secretions, place in sniffing position, warm, dry, stimulate.
  • Labored breathing or cyanosis: Provide blow-by Oxygen.
  • HR < 100, gasping or apnea: BVM with room air, 1 breath q 1-1.5 seconds (40-60/min).
  • Reassess after 30 seconds of good chest rise/fall:
    • HR > 60 but < 100: Perform ventilation corrective actions (MR SOPA). Continue BVM until HR > 100.
    • HR < 60: Add supplemental O2 and initiate CPR (3 compressions : 1 breath). Discontinue CPR when HR > 60.
  • Perform continuous SpO2 monitoring via infant's RIGHT wrist.
SL 2+
  • Cardiac Monitoring if HR < 100.
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry).
  • Airway Management: Consider SGA if BVM is ineffective or HR < 60.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access (IV/IO) if performing BVM or CPR.
SL 4+
  • HR < 60 after BVM and 1 min of CPR: Epinephrine (1:10,000) 0.01mg/kg (0.1mL/kg) IV/IO, repeat q 3-5 min.
  • Unresponsive to resuscitation and known hemorrhage: LR 10mL/kg IV/IO.
  • After 5 min of CPR without improvement, check BGL. If < 40mg/dL: D10W 2mL/kg IV/IO.

title: E-1: General Patient Care (Pediatric)
content:
Key Concepts

Use Pediatric Assessment Triangle (Appearance, Work of Breathing, Circulation to Skin). Consider "toe-to-head" approach for stable patients.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • If signs of puberty or > 60kg, use Adult Protocols.
  • Manage Immediate Life Threats.
  • E-2, Airway Management. Oxygen to keep SpO2 ≥ 94%.
  • Monitor Vitals (HR, RR, BP, SpO2, Pain, Temp).
  • Check BGL as required.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access (IV/IO). Use proximal tibia for IO.
  • Use Blood/Fluid Warmers for trauma/hypovolemia.

title: E-2: Airway Management (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Allow patient to maintain position of comfort.
  • Open airway, suction PRN. Use NPA/OPA as indicated.
  • BVM Ventilations: Neonatal (see D-5), 24hrs-12yrs (20-30/min), >12yrs (see B-2).
  • Choking: >1yr (Heimlich), <1yr (5 back blows/5 chest thrusts).
  • High Flow Nasal Cannula - 8 LPM if SpO2 < 85%.
SL 2+
  • Supraglottic Airway (SGA) as needed (PRIMARY for Cardiac Arrest).
  • EtCO2 (Capnometry).
  • Needle Thoracentesis for tension pneumothorax (2nd ICS mid-clavicular preferred).
SL 3+
  • PEEP Valve with BVM for hypoxia.
  • Consider CPAP for severe respiratory distress.
SL 4+
  • Cricothyrotomy (>8yrs surgical, <8yrs needle).
  • Post-Advanced Airway Sedation: Ketamine 2mg/kg.

title: E-3: Nausea / Vomiting & Abdominal Pain (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Position of comfort, provide reassurance. Ensure suction is available.
  • Check BGL.
SL 3+
  • Nausea/Vomiting:
    • 20–40kg: Ondansetron 2mg ODT PO, repeat x1.
    • >40kg: Ondansetron 4mg ODT PO, repeat x1.
  • Vascular Access if hypotensive.
SL 4+
  • Nausea/Vomiting: Ondansetron 0.1mg/kg IV/IO (max single dose 4mg), repeat x1.
  • Pain Management per E-4.

Additional Considerations

Emergent causes of peds abdominal pain: Appendicitis, Intussusception, Volvulus, DKA, Non-Accidental Trauma, Torsion (Ovarian/Testicular).

title: E-4: Pain Management (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Determine pain score (Wong-Baker).
  • Position of comfort, ice packs/splints.
SL 3+
  • MILD Pain: Acetaminophen 15mg/kg PO.
  • MODERATE to SEVERE (> 8yo w/ OLMC): Ketamine 2mg/kg IN/IM.
  • Monitor V/S and EtCO2 for controlled substances.
SL 4+
  • MODERATE to SEVERE:
    • SBP > Age-specific hypotension: Fentanyl 1mcg/kg IV/IO/IM, repeat x1.
    • > 8yo with any SBP: Ketamine 0.2mg/kg IV/IO or 2mg/kg IN/IM.
  • Opioid Reversal: Naloxone.

title: E-5: Cardiac Arrest (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Establish pulselessness/apnea; call for ALS/additional resources.
  • Initiate high-quality CPR (15:2 for 2-rescuer) / Apply AED (use Peds pads).
  • E-2, Airway Management / Oxygen.
  • If >60kg or signs of puberty, see B-5, Cardiac Arrest.
  • Assess for BGL & Hypothermia.
  • Treat H's & T's.
  • ROSC: See E-6, ROSC (Peds).
SL 2+
  • Capnometry - Maintain > 10mmHg.
  • Supraglottic Airway (SGA) - As soon as possible.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: Establish ASAP.
  • Epinephrine (1mg/10mL) 0.01mg/kg IV/IO, q 3-5 min.
  • Hypovolemia: LR 20mL/kg IV/IO.
  • Hypoglycemia: Dextrose 10% 5mL/kg IV/IO.
SL 4+
  • VF / Pulseless VT: Defibrillate at 2 J/kg, then 4 J/kg.
  • After first shock & Epi: Amiodarone 5mg/kg IV/IO.
  • Torsades de Pointes: Magnesium Sulfate 25-50mg/kg IV/IO.
  • Hyperkalemia: Calcium Gluconate 60mg/kg, Sodium Bicarbonate 1mEq/kg, Albuterol 10mg Nebulized.

title: E-6: ROSC & Post-Arrest Care (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Treat H's & T's, Hypothermia, BGL.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access and fluid bolus 20mL/kg LR for hypotension.
SL 4+
  • Post-Advanced Airway Sedation: Ketamine 2mg/kg.
  • Persistent hypotension: Epinephrine or Norepinephrine drip.

title: E-7: Bradycardia (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • HR < 60 bpm with poor perfusion despite oxygenation/ventilation: START CPR.
  • Check BGL.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access.
  • If HR remains < 60 after 2 min CPR: Epinephrine (1:10,000) 0.01mg/kg IV/IO q 3-5 min.
SL 4+
  • Increased Vagal Tone/AV Block: Atropine 0.02mg/kg IV/IO.
  • Transcutaneous Pacing if no improvement. Sedate with Ketamine 1mg/kg if time allows.
  • Treat suspected Beta Blocker/CCB Overdose or Hyperkalemia.

title: E-8: Tachycardia, Narrow Complex (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

Infants < 1 yr: HR > 220 bpm; Children > 1 yr: HR > 180 bpm

SL 3+
  • Vascular Access. If hypotensive, 20mL/kg LR bolus.
SL 4+
  • Unstable/Symptomatic (Hypotension/AMS): Synchronized Cardioversion at 0.5-1 J/kg, then 2 J/kg. Sedate with Ketamine if time allows.
  • Stable SVT: Attempt Vagal Maneuvers. Adenosine 0.1mg/kg rapid IV/IO (max 6mg), then 0.2mg/kg (max 12mg).

title: E-9: Tachycardia, Wide Complex (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 4+
  • Unstable/Symptomatic: Synchronized Cardioversion at 0.5-1 J/kg, then 2 J/kg. Sedate if time allows.
  • Stable/Asymptomatic (Regular/Monomorphic): Consult OLMC. Adenosine 0.1mg/kg then 0.2mg/kg.
  • Torsades de Pointes (with pulse): Magnesium Sulfate 25-50mg/kg IV/IO.
  • Treat suspected Hyperkalemia.

title: E-10: Altered Mental Status / BRUE (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Check pupillary response, treat suspected overdose (E-15).
  • Check for Seizure/Postictal state (E-17).
  • Check for Head Trauma (F-3).
  • Check BGL (E-14).

Brief Resolved Unexplained Event (BRUE)

An event in an infant < 1 year with no obvious explanation, lasting < 1 min, and resolved on arrival. May include change in breathing, color, tone, or responsiveness. ALL patients with a suspected BRUE should be transported.

title: E-11: Anaphylaxis / Allergic Reaction (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Moderate/Severe: Assist with patient's prescribed Epinephrine Autoinjector.
SL 3+
  • Moderate/Severe: Administer agency Epinephrine Autoinjector (0.15mg or 0.3mg based on weight).
  • Wheezing: Albuterol & Ipratropium nebulized.
  • Mild Reaction: Diphenhydramine 1mg/kg.
SL 4+
  • Moderate/Severe: Diphenhydramine 2mg/kg, Epinephrine (1:1000) 0.15mg IM, Dexamethasone 0.5mg/kg.
  • Refractory hypotension: Epinephrine Drip.

title: E-12: Asthma / Reactive Airway Disease (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Severe Asthma: Assist with patient's prescribed Epinephrine Autoinjector.
SL 3+
  • Wheezing: Albuterol & Ipratropium nebulized.
  • Severe distress: Epinephrine Autoinjector (0.15mg or 0.3mg).
  • Consider CPAP.
SL 4+
  • Audible wheezing: Dexamethasone 0.5mg/kg.
  • If unimproved: Epinephrine (1:1000) IM, Magnesium Sulfate 40mg/kg IV/IO.
  • Refractory: Epinephrine Drip.

title: E-13: Croup / Epiglottitis / Bronchiolitis
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Minimize stimulation, keep child calm. Blow-by oxygen as tolerated.
SL 2+
  • Stridor or barking cough: 3mL NS 0.9% nebulized.
  • Wheezing: Albuterol & Ipratropium nebulized.
  • Suspected Epiglottitis: Supportive care ONLY. Do not inspect airway. Prepare for difficult airway.
SL 4+
  • Unresponsive to nebulized saline: Epinephrine 3mg/3mL nebulized.
  • Suspected Croup: Consider Dexamethasone 0.5mg/kg.

title: E-14: Diabetic Emergencies (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Hypoglycemia & can swallow: Oral Glucose 15g PO.
SL 3+
  • Hypoglycemia & unable to swallow/AMS:
    • <50kg: Dextrose 10% (D10W) 5mL/kg IV/IO.
    • >50kg: Dextrose 10% (D10W) 250mL IV/IO.
  • BGL > 300mg/dL: LR 10mL/kg.
SL 4+
  • Hypoglycemia & no IV/IO access:
    • <20kg: Glucagon 0.5mg IM.
    • >20kg: Glucagon 1mg IM.

title: E-15: Overdose / Toxic Ingestion (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Contact Poison Control (1-800-222-1222).
  • Suspected Opioid Overdose: Naloxone Nasal Spray 4mg IN.
SL 4+
  • Suspected Opioid Overdose: Naloxone 0.1mg/kg IV/IO (<5yrs or <20kg) or 2mg IV/IO (>=5yrs or >=20kg).
  • Treat TCA, Beta Blocker, or Calcium Channel Blocker overdoses accordingly.

title: E-16: Sepsis / Septic Shock (Pediatric)
content:
SIRS Criteria

Based on age-specific abnormalities in Temp, HR, RR, or WBC count.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 3+
  • Vascular Access.
  • SBP < age-specific hypotension: LR 20mL/kg IV/IO, repeat PRN to max 60mL/kg.
  • Temp > 100.4°F: Acetaminophen 15mg/kg PO.
SL 4+
  • Refractory hypotension: Norepinephrine drip 0.1-2mcg/kg/min.

title: E-17: Seizures & Post-Seizure Management (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Place in recovery position, keep warm.
  • Check BGL.
SL 3+
  • Febrile Seizure (Temp > 100.4°F): Acetaminophen 15mg/kg PO.
SL 4+
  • Actively Seizing:
    • Midazolam 0.1mg/kg IV/IO (max 5mg), repeat x1. OR
    • Midazolam 0.2mg/kg IN/IM (max 10mg), repeat x1.

Additional Considerations

Febrile seizures are common from 6 months to 5 years. Status Epilepticus is seizure activity > 5 mins.

title: E-18: Shock (non-Trauma) / Hypotension (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 3+
  • Vascular Access x2.
  • SBP < age-specific hypotension:
    • Hypovolemic, Septic, Neurogenic, Anaphylactic: LR 20mL/kg IV/IO, to max 60mL/kg.
    • Cardiogenic: LR 10mL/kg IV/IO, to max 30mL/kg.
SL 4+
  • Refractory hypotension: Norepinephrine or Epinephrine Drip.

title: B-19: Bites & Envenomations - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
Bites & Envenomations (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (B-19). Use pediatric dosing for medications as appropriate.

SL 4+
  • Spider/Scorpion Bite with severe muscle spasms:
    • Midazolam 0.1 mg/kg IV/IO (max 5mg) OR
    • Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IM/IN (max 10mg).

title: G-1b: CO Poisoning / Smoke Inhalation & Cyanide Toxicity - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
CO Poisoning / Smoke Inhalation & Cyanide (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (G-1b). Use pediatric dosing for medications.

Additional Considerations

Transport to a hyperbaric facility for SpCO > 15%.

title: Protocol B-14: Airborne Pathogens - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
Airborne Pathogens (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (B-14). Use pediatric dosing for medications.

SL 1-5
  • Wheezing/Distress: Use MDI with spacer. 4 puffs, repeat q 10 mins PRN.

title: B-22: Hyperthermia / Heat Injuries - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
Hyperthermia / Heat Injuries (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (B-22). Use pediatric dosing for medications.

SL 4+
  • If shivering occurs during cooling:
    • Midazolam 0.1mg/kg IV/IO (max 5mg) OR
    • Midazolam 0.2mg/kg IM/IN (max 10mg).

title: B-23: Hypothermia / Cold Injuries - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
Hypothermia / Cold Injuries (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (B-23). Follow the same guidelines for assessment and rewarming.

title: B-26: Drowning / Submersion - PEDIATRIC REFERENCE
content:
Drowning / Submersion (Pediatric)

This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (B-26), with the following key differences for initial resuscitation.

  • Unresponsive: Give 5 initial rescue breaths via BVM.
  • If pulse is present (≥60 bpm), continue rescue breathing at 1 breath every 2-3 seconds.
  • If no pulse or HR is ≤60 bpm, start CPR per E-5.

title: F-1: Trauma, General (Pediatric)
content:
Key Concepts: MARCH-PAWS

  • M – Massive hemorrhage
  • A – Airway
  • R – Respiration
  • C – Circulation
  • H – Hypothermia/Head Injury
  • ---
  • P – Pain
  • A – Antibiotics
  • W – Wounds
  • S – Splints

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Perform triage and life-saving interventions based on MARCH-PAWS.
  • Massive Hemorrhage: Apply tourniquets/hemostatic dressings.
  • Airway: Manage airway per E-2.
  • Respirations: Apply occlusive dressings to chest/abdominal wounds.
  • Circulation: Check pulses and TQ placement.
  • Hypothermia/Head Injury: Keep warm, manage head injuries per F-3.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access: 2 large bore IVs or IOs.
  • Fluid Resuscitation:
    • WITH Head Injury: LR to SBP > 10mmHg above age-specific hypotension.
    • WITHOUT Head Injury: LR to SBP > age-specific hypotension.

title: F-2: Burns (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • STOP the burning process. Treat other life-threatening trauma first.
  • Thermal Burn: <10% TBSA irrigate and cover with dry sterile dressing. >10% TBSA cover with burn sheet.
  • Chemical Burn: Brush off powder, remove clothing, flush with water/saline for at least 15 min.
  • Electrical/Lightning: Scene safety first. If arrest, see E-5.
  • Keep patient warm.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access if >20% TBSA 2nd/3rd degree burns.
  • Fluid Resuscitation (>20% TBSA): Use Modified Brooke Formula (2mL x kg x %TBSA) / 2 / 8 hrs. Use a length-based tape for estimation.
SL 4+
  • Consider early advanced airway for suspected inhalation injury.

title: F-3: Head/Facial Injuries (Pediatric)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Airway Management: Do NOT use NPAs with significant facial trauma. Maintain SpO2 ≥ 93%.
  • Elevate head of stretcher 30°.
SL 2+
  • Obtain Pediatric GCS. Trauma Alert if GCS < 13.
  • EtCO2 Target: 35-40mmHg. Herniation: 30-35mmHg.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access.
  • Hypotension: LR to maintain SBP > 10mmHg above age-specific minimum.
SL 4+
  • Consider advanced airway for severe injuries.
  • Refractory hypotension: Epinephrine or Norepinephrine drip.

*Evidence of Herniation

  • Cushing’s Triad: Bradycardia, Hypertension, Irregular Respirations.
  • Posturing, rapid decline in mental status, pupil changes.

title: C-4-Peds: Epistaxis (Pediatric)
content:
This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (C-4) with pediatric considerations.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • If actively bleeding: Provide direct pressure by pinching the anterior portion of the nose with moderate force for 5 - 10 min continuously (tilt head forward).
  • If unable to stop bleeding, have patient blow nose to remove clots and reapply pressure.
  • Ensure suction is available for posterior bleeds draining into oropharynx.
SL 3+
  • If bleeding continues despite pressure (only for >6 y/o): Oxymetazoline (Afrin) 2 sprays in the affected nare(s).
  • Establish vascular access for significant/uncontrolled bleeding.

Additional Considerations

Encourage patients to spit out blood to prevent nausea & vomiting. Consider foreign body in nose for unilateral, foul-smelling discharge/bleeding.

title: C-5-Peds: Eye Injuries (Pediatric)
content:
This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (C-5). Pain management and sedation should follow pediatric protocols.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Perform basic visual exam (can they track objects, see shapes?).
  • Penetrating object: DO NOT remove; stabilize in place.
  • No penetrating object: Apply rigid eye shield, touching only orbital bones.
  • Extruded eyeball: Place moist, sterile dressing on top; cover with eye shield.
  • Elevate head of stretcher to 30°.
  • Eye Irrigation (for debris/chemicals, NOT penetrating injury): Irrigate with sterile water, NS, or LR.
SL 3+
  • Chemical burns: Tetracaine is NOT approved for pediatrics in this protocol. Focus on copious irrigation. Contact OLMC for guidance.

title: C-7-Peds: Spinal Motion Restriction (Pediatric)
content:
This protocol refers to the Adult Protocol (C-7) with pediatric considerations.

Spinal Motion Restriction Algorithm

SMR is NOT indicated for penetrating trauma to head, neck or torso.

Indications for SMR following BLUNT trauma include any of the following:

  • Acutely altered level of consciousness (e.g., GCS < 15, evidence of intoxication).
  • Torticollis (patient unable to move neck from abnormal position).
  • Midline neck or back pain and/or tenderness.
  • Focal neurologic signs and/or symptoms.
  • Anatomic deformity of the spine.
  • Distracting circumstances or injury.
  • High-risk mechanism (e.g., high-impact MVC, diving injury).

Pediatric Considerations

  • Children have larger heads relative to their bodies. Padding may be needed under the torso (from shoulders to hips) to maintain neutral alignment when on a flat surface.
  • Use appropriately sized C-collars.
  • Infants and toddlers may be best immobilized in their own car seat if the seat is not damaged.

title: G-1a: Altitude Illness (Adult)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Begin Descent Immediately.
  • B-2, Airway Management / Oxygen.
SL 3+
  • Vascular Access.
  • Suspected Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS): Acetazolamide 250mg PO, Dexamethasone 4mg IV/IO/PO.
  • Suspected High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): Dexamethasone 10mg IV/IO/IM/PO.
  • Suspected High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE): If SBP > 100mmHg, Nifedipine 30mg ER tablet PO.

Additional Considerations

No medication is as effective as descent and oxygen. HACE presents as AMS with ataxia. HAPE presents with progressive dyspnea, cough, and hypoxia.

title: G-1b: CO Poisoning / Smoke Inhalation / Cyanide
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Ensure scene safety. Remove patient from exposure.
  • Provide 100% O2 via NRB regardless of SpO2.
  • Determine SpCO if equipped. Treat and transport for SpCO > 12% or symptomatic patients with SpCO > 4%.
SL 4+
  • High clinical suspicion for cyanide toxicity: Hydroxocobalamin 70mg/kg IV/IO (max 5g) over 15 min. (Rapid push in cardiac arrest).

title: G-1c: Decompression Illness (Aerospace)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Provide 100% O2 via NRB.
  • Contact OLMC to discuss transport to Hyperbaric Treatment Facility and notify Flight Surgeon.
SL 2+
  • If available, use Aviator's Mask.
  • Consider CPAP if Aviator's mask is unavailable or SpO2 remains low.
  • Needle decompress for tension pneumothorax.

Additional Considerations

Occurs when nitrogen bubbles form in the bloodstream after rapid altitude changes. Symptoms can occur up to 72 hours later. High-flow oxygen helps "denitrify" the blood. If transporting by air, cabin altitude should be < 1000ft.

title: G-1d: Decompression Sickness (Diving)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Initiate 15L NRB regardless of SpO2.
  • Place patient in supine position.
  • Contact OLMC to discuss transport to Hyperbaric Treatment Facility.
  • Prevent hypothermia.

Additional Considerations

Arterial Gas Embolism (AGE) usually appears within 10 minutes of surfacing. Decompression Sickness (DCS) "The Bends" can have a slower onset. Contact Divers Alert Network (+1-919-684-9111) for consultation.

title: G-2a: Mass Casualty Incidents (MCI)
content:
MCI Guidance

  • Follow local/installation guidance. Initial responders focus on triage once scene is secured.
  • Incident Command (IC) is the lead on ALL MCIs.
  • Triage systems (SALT, START) are used to prioritize patients.
  • Move triaged patients to a Casualty Collection Point (CCP).
  • Continuously re-triage patients. If a patient's condition changes, update their triage category.

title: G-2b: Triage - SALT (Adults ONLY)
content:
SALT Triage

Sort, Assess, Life-Saving Interventions, Transport

Step 1: Sort (Global Sorting)

  • 1st (Still/Obvious Life Threats): Assess patients who are still and those with obvious life threats first.
  • 2nd (Waving/Purposeful Movement): Assess "walking wounded" last.

Step 2: Assess (Individual Assessment)

  • Control major hemorrhage.
  • Open airway (if child, give 2 rescue breaths).
  • Decompress chest.
  • Administer auto-injector antidotes.
  • Breathing? No -> DECEASED. Yes ->
  • Follows commands or makes purposeful movements? No -> IMMEDIATE. Yes ->
  • Has peripheral pulse? No -> IMMEDIATE. Yes ->
  • Not in respiratory distress? Major hemorrhage controlled? No -> IMMEDIATE. Yes ->
  • Likely to survive given current resources? No -> EXPECTANT. Yes -> DELAYED.

title: G-2c: Triage (START / JumpSTART)
content:
START Triage (Adults)

Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment is based on respirations, perfusion, and mental status.

  1. "Can you walk?" All who can are triaged MINOR (Green).
  2. Assess Respirations:
    • Not breathing → Open airway. Still not breathing → DECEASED (Black).
    • Breathing after opening airway → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Breathing > 30/min or < 10/min → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Breathing 10-30/min → Go to next step.
  3. Assess Perfusion:
    • Radial pulse absent or Cap refill > 2 seconds → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Radial pulse present or Cap refill < 2 seconds → Go to next step.
  4. Assess Mental Status:
    • Cannot follow simple commands ("squeeze my hand") → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Can follow simple commands → DELAYED (Yellow).

JumpSTART Triage (Pediatric)

Modified for children who appear to be between ages 1-8.

  1. "Can you walk?" All who can are triaged MINOR (Green).
  2. Assess Breathing:
    • Apneic → Open airway. Still apneic but has pulse → Give 5 rescue breaths.
    • Still apneic after breaths → DECEASED (Black).
    • Starts breathing after breaths → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Respiratory Rate < 15 or > 45/min → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Respiratory Rate 15-45/min → Go to next step.
  3. Assess Perfusion:
    • No palpable peripheral pulse → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • Palpable peripheral pulse → Go to next step.
  4. Assess Mental Status (AVPU):
    • "P" (Pain) or "U" (Unresponsive) → IMMEDIATE (Red).
    • "A" (Alert), "V" (Verbal), or "P" (Pain - appropriately localizes) → DELAYED (Yellow).

title: G-2d: Helicopter Landing Zone (HLZ) Operations
content:
LZ Coordinator Responsibilities

  • Command and secure the LZ (ideally 100x100 feet).
  • Establish radio contact with aircraft to provide LZ description, obstacles, and wind conditions.
  • Keep bystanders 100-150 feet away.

Helicopter Safety

  • The pilot/aircrew control all activity around the aircraft.
  • NEVER walk around the tail rotor. Approach/depart from the side or as directed.
  • Approach in a calm, slow manner. No running.
  • Do not carry anything above your head.
  • Secure all loose equipment (blankets, etc.).

title: G-2e: Scene Rehabilitation
content:
Patient Care

  1. Complete decon and remove gear before entering rehab. Treat life-threats immediately.
  2. Check-in all personnel and log baseline vitals (HR, BP, RR, SpO2, Temp, SpCO if indicated).
  3. Assess vitals:
    • HR ≥ 100 bpm: Obtain orthostatics, initiate IV fluids. Transport if no improvement.
    • SBP ≤ 90 mmHg: Treat for shock, transport.
    • SpCO > 4% w/ symptoms: Treat per G-1b, transport.
    • S/Sx of Hypo/Hyperthermia: Treat per appropriate protocol.
  4. ALL personnel MUST consume ≥ 12 oz of fluid. Minimum rehab time is based on work duration (e.g., 10 min rehab after one 30-min SCBA).
  5. Reassess vitals before release.

title: G-2f: Exposure / Gross Decontamination
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

  • Coordinate with F&ES/IC regarding staging and decontamination.
  • Remove contaminated clothing. Blot off remaining contaminant before irrigation.

POL (Fuel) Exposure:

  • Eyes: Flush with water/saline for at least 15 min.
  • Skin: Flush with water for 2-3 min, wash with soap.
  • Ingestion: Supportive care, do NOT induce vomiting.

OC/OS (Pepper) Spray Exposure:

  • Eyes: Flush with water/saline for at least 15 min.
  • Skin: Blot away residual, flush with water for 15 min, wash with soap.

Hydrazine Exposure:

  • Neurotoxin, caustic, rapidly absorbed through skin. Seizures are common presentation.
  • Eyes/Skin: Flush with water for at least 15 min, wash with soap.
  • Be prepared to treat seizures (B-28). Transport for evaluation.

title: G-2g: Interfacility Transports (IFT)
content:
Key Concepts

  • EMS mission is prehospital 9-1-1 response. IFT is the responsibility of the MTF.
  • Non-emergency IFT will not be performed by EMS, except in time of disaster.
  • EMS will only perform an IFT if it is a time-sensitive issue of life, limb, or eyesight AND the MTF's standard process cannot support the transfer in time.
  • EMS will only transport to approved destinations (ED, ICU, OR, Cath Lab).
  • EMS personnel will not monitor or administer procedures outside their scope as defined by the JPECP.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

  • Sending physician determines level of care required (BLS, ALS, SCT).
  • All IFTs require a minimum of two EMS personnel (SL2+). Additional staff (RN, RT) may accompany but not replace EMS members.
  • A written order (SF 600 or similar) is required for any IV infusion. EMS may not titrate drips unless listed within their skill level in the JPECP.
  • Manage medical emergencies enroute per JPECP.

title: G-2h: LE Transport of Psychiatric Patients
content:
Key Concepts

This protocol applies to installations with agreements for Law Enforcement (LE) to transport patients in mental health crisis.

Clinical Practice Guidelines (SL2+)

  • Assess patient vital signs prior to LE transport.
  • Refer to appropriate protocol and/or consult OLMC if any of the following are present:
    • HR > 120 bpm
    • SBP ≤ 90 mmHg
    • RR > 30
    • BGL < 60 mg/dL or > 200 mg/dL
  • If any of the above criteria are met, EMS will transport to an appropriate ER.
  • EMS will not transport patients to Freestanding Psychiatric Facilities; LE transport is appropriate for medically cleared patients.

title: G-2i: Medical Care of Military Working Animals
content:
Key Concepts

  • Care is limited to life, limb, or eyesight preservation or to limit suffering when veterinary personnel are not available.
  • Safety of responding personnel is the highest priority. Muzzle the animal. Utilize the handler if possible.
  • EMS will transport Military Working Animals (MWA) to a Veterinary Treatment Facility (VTF) if clinically indicated.
  • EMS will NOT transport non-DoD animals.

Clinical Practice Guidelines

  • Assess vital signs (understand they differ from human norms).
  • Provide Oxygen.
  • Treat illness/injury IAW applicable protocols, adapting as necessary for non-human patients.
  • Consult OLMC.
  • Reference JTS Clinical Practice Guideline for Military Working Dogs for more details.

title: G-3a: Organophosphate / Nerve Agent Exposure
content:
Key Signs/Symptoms (SLUDGE / DUMBBELS)

Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, GI Upset, Emesis / Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bradycardia, Bronchorrhea, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation

Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Patient must be fully decontaminated before transport.
  • B-2/E-2 Airway Management / Oxygen.
  • Administer auto-injectors based on age and severity (up to 3 sets).
    • Mild: Atropine only.
    • Moderate: Atropine and Pralidoxime Chloride (e.g., ATNAA/NAAK).
    • Severe: Higher doses of Atropine/Pralidoxime, plus Diazepam (CANA) for seizures.

title: G-3b: Exposure / Decontamination (Ionizing Radiation)
content:
Clinical Practice Guidelines

SL 1-5
  • Scene safety: Limit time, increase distance, use shielding.
  • Do not delay treatment of life-threatening injuries for decontamination.
  • Remove contaminated clothing at earliest practical opportunity.
  • Manage trauma and medical issues per applicable protocols.
  • Nausea/Vomiting: See B-3.
  • Do NOT transport until patient is adequately decontaminated, unless life-threats cannot be mitigated on scene. Wrap patient in a sheet for transport.
  • For expert consultation, call AFRRI MRAT (301-295-0530).

title: Acetaminophen
content:
Acetaminophen

Class:

Analgesic, Antipyretic

Mechanism:

Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis in the CNS, reducing pain and fever.

Indications:

Mild pain, fever.

Contraindications:

Severe liver disease, hypersensitivity. Do not administer if taken within the last 4 hours.

Dose (Adult):

1000mg PO.

Dose (Peds):

15mg/kg PO.

Special Notes:

Be aware of the maximum daily dose (4g for adults) from all sources.

title: Acetazolamide
content:
Acetazolamide

Class:

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitor

Mechanism:

Inhibits carbonic anhydrase, reducing hydrogen ion secretion and promoting bicarbonate excretion, which counteracts respiratory alkalosis at altitude.

Indications:

Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS).

Contraindications:

Sulfa allergy (relative), sickle cell anemia, renal or liver disease.

Dose (Adult):

250mg PO.

title: Adenosine
content:
Adenosine

Class:

Antiarrhythmic

Mechanism:

Slows conduction time through AV node; can interrupt re-entrant pathways.

Indications:

SVT (Narrow Complex Tachycardia), Wide Complex Tachycardia (regular/monomorphic)

Contraindications:

2nd or 3rd degree AV block, Sick Sinus Syndrome, WPW.

Dose (Adult):

6mg rapid IV/IO push, followed by 12mg if no conversion.

Dose (Peds):

0.1mg/kg (max 6mg), followed by 0.2mg/kg (max 12mg).

Special Notes:

Administer rapidly followed by a saline flush. Short half-life (<10 sec). Patient may feel a sense of "impending doom" or chest pressure.

title: Albumin 25%
content:
Albumin 25%

Class:

Colloid, Plasma Volume Expander

Mechanism:

Increases intravascular oncotic pressure, drawing fluid from the interstitial space into the intravascular space.

Indications:

Hypovolemia in hemorrhagic shock.

Dose (Adult):

100mL IV/IO, repeat PRN to max 200mL.

Dose (Peds):

4mL/kg IV/IO, repeat PRN to max 8mL/kg.

title: Albuterol
content:
Albuterol

Class:

Sympathomimetic, Bronchodilator (Beta-2 Agonist)

Mechanism:

Relaxes bronchial smooth muscle, resulting in bronchodilation.

Indications:

Wheezing, bronchospasm (Asthma, COPD, Anaphylaxis), Hyperkalemia.

Contraindications:

Hypersensitivity.

Dose (Adult/Peds):

2.5mg in 3mL saline via nebulizer.

Special Notes:

May cause tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. Use with caution in patients with known heart disease.

title: Amiodarone
content:
Amiodarone

Class:

Antiarrhythmic

Mechanism:

Blocks sodium, potassium, and calcium channels, prolonging the action potential.

Indications:

Pulseless VT/VF, Wide Complex Tachycardia.

Contraindications:

Bradycardia, heart block, cardiogenic shock.

Dose (Adult Cardiac Arrest):

300mg IV/IO push, may repeat with 150mg.

Dose (Peds Cardiac Arrest):

5mg/kg IV/IO bolus, may repeat up to 2 times.

Special Notes:

May cause hypotension and bradycardia. Monitor patient closely.

title: Aspirin
content:
Aspirin (ASA)

Class:

Platelet inhibitor, Anti-inflammatory

Mechanism:

Inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking thromboxane A2 synthesis.

Indications:

Chest pain suggestive of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

Contraindications:

Hypersensitivity, active bleeding ulcer.

Dose (Adult):

324mg (four 81mg tablets) chewed.

Special Notes:

Not for use in pediatric patients with febrile illness due to risk of Reye's syndrome.

title: Atropine
content:
Atropine

Class:

Anticholinergic, Parasympatholytic

Mechanism:

Blocks the action of acetylcholine at parasympathetic sites, increasing heart rate.

Indications:

Symptomatic bradycardia, organophosphate poisoning.

Contraindications:

None in an emergency setting. Use with caution in ACS.

Dose (Adult Bradycardia):

1mg IV/IO push, repeat every 3-5 minutes to a max of 3mg.

Dose (Peds Bradycardia):

0.02mg/kg IV/IO (min dose 0.1mg, max single dose 0.5mg).

Special Notes:

Ineffective for high-degree AV blocks and post-transplant patients.

title: Calcium Gluconate
content:
