Calcium Gluconate

Class:

Electrolyte

Mechanism:

Moderates nerve and muscle activity, increases cardiac contractility.

Indications:

Hyperkalemia, calcium channel blocker overdose, beta blocker overdose, crush injury.

Dose (Adult):

2g IV/IO over 2-5 min.

Dose (Peds):

60mg/kg IV/IO (max 2g).

Special Notes:

Use with caution in patients on digoxin. Can cause tissue necrosis if it extravasates.

title: Dexamethasone
content:
Dexamethasone

Class:

Corticosteroid

Mechanism:

Decreases inflammation by suppressing neutrophil migration and reducing inflammatory mediators.

Indications:

Anaphylaxis, asthma/COPD exacerbation, croup, refractory shock.

Contraindications:

Hypersensitivity, systemic fungal infections.

Dose (Adult):

10mg IV/IO/IM/PO.

Dose (Peds):

0.5mg/kg (max 10mg) IV/IO/IM/PO.

title: Dextrose 10%
content:
Dextrose 10% (D10W)

Class:

Carbohydrate

Mechanism:

Rapidly increases serum glucose levels.

Indications:

Hypoglycemia.

Dose (Adult):

250mL IV/IO.

Dose (Peds):

5mL/kg IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Check BGL before and after administration. Less damaging to veins than D50.

title: Diazepam (CANA)
content:
Diazepam (CANA)

Class:

Benzodiazepine

Mechanism:

Increases GABA affinity, preventing further excitation of cells.

Indications:

Nerve Agent Anticonvulsant.

Dose:

10mg auto-injector.

title: Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
content:
Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)

Class:

Antihistamine

Mechanism:

Blocks H1 histamine receptors.

Indications:

Allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, dystonic reactions.

Dose (Adult):

25-50mg IV/IO/IM.

Dose (Peds):

1-2mg/kg IV/IO/IM (max 50mg).

Special Notes:

Can cause drowsiness and anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, blurred vision).

title: Epinephrine (Epi)
content:
Epinephrine

Class:

Sympathomimetic, Alpha/Beta Agonist

Mechanism:

Stimulates alpha, beta-1, and beta-2 receptors, causing vasoconstriction, increased heart rate/contractility, and bronchodilation.

Indications:

Cardiac Arrest, Anaphylaxis, Severe Asthma, Symptomatic Bradycardia.

Dose (Adult Cardiac Arrest):

1mg (1:10,000) IV/IO every 3-5 minutes.

Dose (Adult Anaphylaxis):

0.3-0.5mg (1:1,000) IM.

Dose (Peds Cardiac Arrest):

0.01mg/kg (1:10,000) IV/IO every 3-5 minutes.

Special Notes:

Increases myocardial oxygen demand.

title: Ertapenem
content:
Ertapenem

Class:

Antibiotic

Mechanism:

Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Indications:

Open traumatic wounds with prolonged transport (>60 min).

Dose (Adult):

1g IV/IO over 30 min or 1g IM.

title: Fentanyl
content:
Fentanyl

Class:

Opioid Analgesic

Mechanism:

Binds to opiate receptors in the CNS, producing analgesia and sedation.

Indications:

Moderate to severe pain.

Contraindications:

Hypotension (SBP < 100 mmHg), respiratory depression, severe head injury.

Dose (Adult):

1mcg/kg IV/IO/IM/IN (max single dose 100mcg).

Dose (Peds):

1mcg/kg IV/IO/IM.

Special Notes:

Rapid push may cause chest wall rigidity. Have naloxone available.

title: Glucagon
content:
Glucagon

Class:

Hormone, Antihypoglycemic

Mechanism:

Increases blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis in the liver. Also has positive inotropic and chronotropic effects.

Indications:

Hypoglycemia (when IV access is unavailable), beta-blocker/calcium channel blocker overdose.

Dose (Adult Hypoglycemia):

1mg IM.

Special Notes:

Requires glycogen stores to be effective. May cause nausea and vomiting.

title: Hydroxocobalamin
content:
Hydroxocobalamin

Class:

Antidote

Mechanism:

Binds with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine.

Indications:

Suspected or known cyanide toxicity.

Dose (Adult/Peds):

70mg/kg IV/IO over 15 min (max 5g).

Special Notes:

Causes reddish discoloration of skin, plasma, and urine.

title: Hypertonic Saline 3%
content:
Hypertonic Saline 3%

Class:

Electrolyte

Mechanism:

Creates an osmotic gradient to draw fluid from interstitial space into the intravascular space, reducing cerebral edema.

Indications:

Head injury with signs of herniation.

Dose (Adult):

250mL IV/IO.

title: Ipratropium Bromide
content:
Ipratropium Bromide

Class:

Anticholinergic, Bronchodilator

Mechanism:

Blocks acetylcholine receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, causing bronchodilation.

Indications:

Bronchospasm associated with asthma and COPD.

Dose (Adult/Peds):

0.5mg in 2.5-3mL saline via nebulizer, usually administered with Albuterol.

title: Ketamine
content:
Ketamine

Class:

General Anesthetic, Dissociative

Mechanism:

Produces a dissociative state, providing analgesia, sedation, and amnesia while maintaining airway reflexes.

Indications:

Pain management (especially in hypotensive patients), sedation for procedures, combative patients.

Contraindications:

Severe hypertension, known schizophrenia (relative).

Dose (Adult Analgesia):

0.2mg/kg IV/IO or 0.5mg/kg IM/IN.

Dose (Adult Sedation):

2mg/kg IV/IO/IN or 4mg/kg IM.

Special Notes:

Can cause emergence reactions (hallucinations, delirium). Often increases heart rate and blood pressure.

title: Lidocaine
content:
Lidocaine

Class:

Antiarrhythmic, Anesthetic

Mechanism:

Blocks sodium channels, suppressing automaticity in the ventricle.

Indications:

Ventricular tachycardia (especially in pregnant patients), IO pain management.

Dose (Adult VT - Pregnant):

100mg slow IV/IO push.

Dose (IO Pain):

40mg slow IO push (Adult), 0.5mg/kg (Peds).

title: Magnesium Sulfate
content:
Magnesium Sulfate

Class:

Electrolyte, Anticonvulsant

Mechanism:

Acts as a CNS depressant and smooth muscle relaxant.

Indications:

Torsades de Pointes, eclamptic seizures, severe asthma.

Dose (Adult Torsades):

2g IV/IO over 2-3 min.

Dose (Adult Eclampsia):

4g IV/IO over 10 min.

Special Notes:

Can cause respiratory depression and hypotension if given too rapidly.

title: Meloxicam
content:
Meloxicam

Class:

NSAID

Mechanism:

Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis, resulting in anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects.

Indications:

Mild pain.

Contraindications:

Hypersensitivity to NSAIDs, history of GI bleed, renal insufficiency.

Dose (Adult):

15mg PO.

title: Metoclopramide
content:
Metoclopramide

Class:

Antiemetic

Mechanism:

Dopamine receptor antagonist, increases GI motility.

Indications:

Nausea/vomiting unresponsive to ondansetron.

Contraindications:

GI bleed/obstruction, seizure history.

Dose (Adult):

5-10mg in 100mL NS IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Risk of extrapyramidal/dystonic reactions.

title: Metoprolol
content:
Metoprolol

Class:

Beta-blocker

Mechanism:

Selectively inhibits beta-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and cardiac output.

Indications:

Narrow complex tachycardia unresponsive to adenosine.

Contraindications:

Bradycardia, hypotension, heart block, CHF.

Dose (Adult):

5mg IV/IO over 2 min, may repeat.

title: Midazolam (Versed)
content:
Midazolam (Versed)

Class:

Benzodiazepine

Mechanism:

Enhances the effects of GABA, producing sedation, amnesia, and anticonvulsant effects.

Indications:

Seizures, sedation for procedures, combative patients.

Contraindications:

Hypotension, respiratory depression, glaucoma (relative).

Dose (Adult Seizure):

5mg IV/IO or 10mg IM/IN.

Dose (Peds Seizure):

0.1mg/kg IV/IO (max 5mg) or 0.2mg/kg IM/IN (max 10mg).

Special Notes:

Monitor respiratory status closely. Can cause hypotension, especially when administered rapidly.

title: Naloxone (Narcan)
content:
Naloxone (Narcan)

Class:

Opioid Antagonist

Mechanism:

Competitively blocks opioid receptor sites, reversing respiratory depression.

Indications:

Opioid overdose with respiratory depression.

Contraindications:

None in an emergency.

Dose (Adult):

0.4-2mg IV/IM/IN, may repeat. Many agencies now use 4mg IN pre-filled device.

Dose (Peds):

0.1mg/kg IV/IM/IN (max single dose 2mg).

Special Notes:

May precipitate acute withdrawal in dependent patients. Titrate to adequate respirations, not full consciousness. Duration may be shorter than the opioid's duration.

title: Nifedipine
content:
Nifedipine

Class:

Calcium Channel Blocker

Mechanism:

Reduces pulmonary vascular resistance and pulmonary artery pressure.

Indications:

High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE).

Contraindications:

Myocardial infarction, SBP < 100 mmHg.

Dose (Adult):

30mg ER tablet PO.

title: Nitroglycerin
content:
Nitroglycerin

Class:

Vasodilator, Antianginal

Mechanism:

Relaxes vascular smooth muscle, dilating coronary arteries and reducing preload and afterload.

Indications:

Chest pain (ACS), pulmonary edema.

Contraindications:

Hypotension (SBP < 100 mmHg), suspected right-sided MI, use of erectile dysfunction medications within 24-48 hours.

Dose (Adult):

0.4mg SL every 3-5 minutes.

Special Notes:

Can cause significant hypotension and headache. Ensure IV access is established.

title: Norepinephrine
content:
Norepinephrine

Class:

Vasopressor, Alpha/Beta Agonist

Mechanism:

Primarily stimulates alpha-receptors causing potent vasoconstriction; minimal beta-1 effects.

Indications:

Cardiogenic, septic, and neurogenic shock; persistent hypotension unresponsive to fluids.

Dose (Adult):

2-12 mcg/min IV/IO infusion, titrated to effect (target SBP > 90 mmHg).

Dose (Peds):

0.1-2 mcg/kg/min IV/IO infusion.

Special Notes:

Potent vasoconstrictor; can cause tissue necrosis if it extravasates. Use a large vein or central line if possible.

title: Ondansetron (Zofran)
content:
Ondansetron (Zofran)

Class:

Antiemetic

Mechanism:

Blocks serotonin (5-HT3) receptors centrally and peripherally.

Indications:

Nausea and vomiting.

Contraindications:

Hypersensitivity, prolonged QT syndrome.

Dose (Adult):

4mg IV/IO/PO (ODT), may repeat once.

Dose (Peds):

0.1mg/kg IV/IO (max 4mg) or by weight for ODT.

Special Notes:

Can be given orally (injection form) if ODT is not available.

title: Oral Glucose
content:
Oral Glucose

Class:

Carbohydrate

Mechanism:

Increases blood glucose levels.

Indications:

Hypoglycemia in a conscious patient who can swallow.

Dose:

15g PO.

title: Oxymetazoline (Afrin)
content:
Oxymetazoline (Afrin)

Class:

Adrenergic Agonist, Vasoconstrictor

Mechanism:

Causes vasoconstriction of nasal mucosa.

Indications:

Epistaxis (nosebleed).

Dose (Adult/Peds >6yo):

2 sprays in the affected nare(s).

title: Oxytocin (Pitocin)
content:
Oxytocin (Pitocin)

Class:

Hormone, Uterine Stimulant

Mechanism:

Stimulates uterine smooth muscle contraction.

Indications:

Postpartum hemorrhage.

Dose (Adult):

10 Units IM or 20 Units in 1000mL LR IV infusion.

Special Notes:

Administer after delivery of the placenta.

title: Pralidoxime Chloride (2-PAM)
content:
Pralidoxime Chloride (2-PAM)

Class:

Antidote, Cholinesterase Reactivator

Mechanism:

Reactivates cholinesterase inactivated by organophosphates.

Indications:

Organophosphate or nerve agent poisoning.

Dose (Adult):

600mg IM via auto-injector (e.g., part of ATNAA/Mark I Kit).

Special Notes:

Must be given with atropine to be effective.

title: Rocuronium
content:
Rocuronium

Class:

Neuromuscular Blocker

Mechanism:

Antagonizes acetylcholine receptors, causing skeletal muscle paralysis.

Indications:

Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI).

Dose (Adult/Peds):

1.2mg/kg IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Patient must be adequately sedated before paralysis. Longer duration than succinylcholine.

title: Sodium Bicarbonate
content:
Sodium Bicarbonate

Class:

Alkalinizing Agent

Mechanism:

Buffers excess hydrogen ions, raising blood pH.

Indications:

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose with wide QRS, severe metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia.

Dose (Adult):

100 mEq IV/IO over 2-5 min.

Dose (Peds):

1 mEq/kg IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Do not mix with other medications, especially calcium. Ensure line is flushed.

title: Succinylcholine
content:
Succinylcholine

Class:

Neuromuscular Blocker, Depolarizing

Mechanism:

Depolarizes the motor endplate, causing fasciculations followed by paralysis.

Indications:

Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI).

Contraindications:

History of malignant hyperthermia, known hyperkalemia, crush injuries > 24 hours old, neuromuscular disorders.

Dose (Adult/Peds):

1.5mg/kg IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Short acting. May cause transient hyperkalemia and bradycardia.

title: Tetracaine 0.5%
content:
Tetracaine 0.5%

Class:

Local Anesthetic

Mechanism:

Blocks nerve impulses by inhibiting sodium ion channels.

Indications:

Ocular chemical burns (to facilitate irrigation).

Dose (Adult):

2 drops in the affected eye.

title: Tranexamic Acid (TXA)
content:
Tranexamic Acid (TXA)

Class:

Antifibrinolytic

Mechanism:

Prevents breakdown of fibrin clots by inhibiting plasminogen activation.

Indications:

Life-threatening hemorrhage from trauma, postpartum hemorrhage.

Contraindications:

Injury > 3 hours old, isolated head injury.

Dose (Adult):

2g IV/IO over 1 min for trauma; 1g IV/IO over 10 min for postpartum hemorrhage.

Special Notes:

Do not administer in the same line as blood products.

title: Whole Blood
content:
Whole Blood

Class:

Blood Product

Mechanism:

Increases blood volume, oxygen-carrying capacity, and clotting factors.

Indications:

Life-threatening hemorrhage, hemorrhagic shock.

Contraindications:

None when indicated.

Dose (Adult):

1 Unit IV/IO, repeat as needed.

Dose (Peds):

10mL/kg IV/IO.

Special Notes:

Monitor for transfusion reactions. Administer Calcium Gluconate with massive transfusion.

title: Drug Bag Email
content:
Below is from the Major overseeing the pharmacy. I am providing to you for your awareness, like every fire department around documentation is paramount. 
 
There must be a paper trail.
 
We received word that there were some issues over the weekend with Fire being resupplied with medication for their ambulance bags/boxes.

To ensure everyone has correct understanding of this process, I wanted to reiterate some details of how the resupply will take place for now, until further details/processes are cemented.

Members from Fire may come to the inpatient pharmacy to have medications utilized in the field be resupplied. 

However, appropriate documentation is required in order to continue to utilize the pharmacy for resupply. 

We must have patient information and as much documentation filled out correctly, especially in regards to controlled substance, so that when we are audited on a monthly basis, we can trace the handling of each medication all the way to its final point of administration. 

If members need training or education on how to fill out the required documentation, we would be happy to provide that. 

Also, to be clear, we do not have additional, already prepped bags/boxes waiting to be swapped out. Items will be resupplied and issued out on an as needed basis. 

This means that it may take a few minutes to reconcile paperwork into the system and generate new paperwork for new medication that is to be issued out. This doesn’t happen instantly and there are multiple steps we require our pharmacy personnel to follow to ensure we follow every federal and local rule that we have to comply with. 

If there are questions/issues related to these procedures, please let us know and we will do our best to address those concerns.
